It is a blatherskite world where bitcoin, blockchain and Frank Timis, once dubbed “the emperor of west African mining”, are mentioned in the same breath.

Yet last week, a battle broke into the open between Argo Blockchain, the crypto-mining newbie that was granted a standard London listing last summer, and First Investments Holding, a Grand Cayman group that Argo claims is controlled by Mr Timis. FIH is Argo’s biggest shareholder with 13.8 per cent. 

Mr Timis is the Australian-Romanian who was convicted twice for heroin possession in his early years. He then headed oil explorer Regal Petroleum in the noughties, which London regulators rapped over the knuckles for misleading investors, and he chaired Aim-quoted iron miner African Minerals until its collapse in 2015.

Business momentum accelerating, credibility concerns subsiding - upgrade to Buy

Ah yes. Spotted this one already.

BE11:17am

That'll be Deutsche Bank putting its "buy" back on Wirecard.

11:17 am
BE11:18am

Here's the blah bit.

JP11:18am

Omg smile

BE11:18am

Wirecard is performing well in a competitive payments industry, successfully expanding its footprint to larger clients while increasingly penetrating its existing merchant/financial institution customer base with value-added services. This should provide further growth and increase the stickiness of its offering. Wirecard has steadily increased its new signings/backlog through new partnerships, product innovation, acquisitions and expansion into new geographies with impressive momentum acceleration in 2018. This should support strong earnings growth for Wirecard in the mid-30% area over '18-'21, in line with fast-growing global payments peers, while its shares trade on a 35-40% discount to the sector (15x '20e EV/EBITDA and 23x P/E vs peers on 26x/36x). This is largely due to recent legal, accounting, and compliance concerns following allegations by the Financial Times and other media sources starting in January. However, with an internal investigation by a reputable law firm in Singapore pointing to only a small financial impact from these issues and Wirecard's long-standing auditor Ernst & Young signing off the 2018 annual report after taking extra time to examine these issues, we do not presume in our analysis that there are major systematic shortcomings in Wirecard's business as a whole – though we do acknowledge the associated risks, including share-price sensitivity to headlines or further findings. In this report we also take a detailed look at Wirecard's take-rate compared to peer Adyen based on new com- pany disclosures. We conclude that Wirecard's take-rate is more comparable to peers than meets the eye. In addition, we take a deep-dive into the company's value- added services (VaS) portfolio, which we expect will become a stabilizing factor for the take-rate. We upgrade the stock to Buy and update our estimates, raising '19/20e EPS by 4/4.5% and our target price to E200 from E170, still valuing Wirecard at a small discount to peers.

11:18 am
BE11:19am

And here's an odd little caveat.

BE11:19am

With this report we also transfer lead coverage of Wirecard to Nooshin Nejati from Johannes Schaller, who will remain secondary analyst.

BE11:19am

Why would that happen then?

BE11:23am

[....] resulting in its share price declining more than 40% in just a few days before starting to recover. Since then, Wirecard has worked to increase its transparency for investors mainly by announcing measures it has taken to improve internal (compliance and other) processes while also releasing more (unaudited) figures to the market on its business, customers and revenue split. Wirecard has acknowledged issues in its Singapore office and commissioned a Singaporean law firm to conduct an independent investigation that has been finalized, according to Wirecard, with the company publishing a summary of the findings, which point to a limited financial impact. This investigation and (ongoing) investigations by local Singapore authorities led Wirecard's auditor EY to take additional time to examine various aspects of the business and accounting; after a three-week delay, it signed off the 2018 annual report. The detailed result of the internal investigation is not available to the public, and the investigations by authorities in Singapore are ongoing. However, based on Wirecard’s summary of the law firm's report and the fact that Ernst & Young has signed the 2018 annual report with an unqualified audit opinion – and assuming that the law and accounting firms have had the appropriate access to documents and systems – we think it is reasonable to believe that financials as presented by Wirecard are appropriately stated, for the purpose of forming our investment view. As we outline in the risks section, if this assumption is misplaced, and Wirecard’s financials are materially restated in the future, the reputational damage to its business could be severe and its share price could again fall sharply.

11:23 am

We see option value only remaining in TCG’s equity. The outlook for FY19 was significantly weaker than expected with guidance for underlying EBIT in 2H19 below 2H18. We cut our underlying FY19E EBIT forecast from £221m to £163m (-26%) which drives underlying EPS -74% to 1.2p. This excludes assumed £87m of SDIs and £1,104m goodwill impairment. We continue to apply 4x and 5x FY19E EBIT multiples for the Tour Op and Airline businesses which points to EV of £738m. Guidance that FY net debt will increase by a similar amount as the 1H18/1H19 move (£361m) points to FY18E net debt of c£750m (Citi £740m) and implies zero equity value. We move to Sell and cut our target price to 0p (from 28p), see inside.

We spoke to numerous debt & equity investors on Thursday/Friday last week to discuss TCG’s prospects and the outlook for equity investors. There was a tight consensus of opinion on the need for a substantial debt for equity swap to provide the group with a sound footing for the future. The vast majority of investors agreed with our opinion that such a process would allow the company to continue to trade in the long term but there was likely to be little or no value for the existing equity holders – an important distinction

We found little push-back on our (we think) bottom of the [sell-side analyst] range [circa] £600m EV valuation for the airline. Although the company reports healthy levels of interest from multiple sources, we have yet to see any indication that the valuation will be materially above our estimates, but this is a key upside risk to our Sell call. Investors have questioned the value of the fleet (eg Ascend data suggests the value of the owned aircraft is around $179m) and slots given that most of the airports that TC operates out of are not capacity constrained

There is a good understanding of the working capital cycle of the business and the importance of the RCF in managing cash through that cycle. Many investors however believe that the group should not have any permanent debt. With this in mind, investors think that the group should seek to convert the £1.0bn of outstanding bonds to equity.

BE11:40am

£1bn .....

11:40 am
BE11:40am

We estimate that such a process could save the group at least £55m in annual interest which could increase profit after tax from our current £22m (FY19E) forecast to over £60m (possibly more if the de-levering could be accompanied by more preferential terms on the RCF). Applying a PE multiple in the range of 6-16x (based on the peer group’s trading range) to these earnings would suggest bond holders could receive equity in the range of £400m-£1,000m or 40-100% of face value compared to the current 45-50% level. A number of investors struggle to see why bond holders would concede any equity value to existing shareholders under such a scenario.

The newer sites, while potentially more profitable, also involve reduced transparency, it said.

Yep, go with that. Not a lot on the corporate side, beyond Ryanair ..... Nor on the Brexit side beyond Brexit .....

JP11:57am

Deutsche down 2.89 pc at pixel, to E6.64.

JP11:57am

Double-digit EPS cuts beyond 2019E
We downgrade to Sell because we don’t expect operating conditions to improve
anytime soon. Deutsche remains a levered market play vulnerable to external events
and rising rates are currently a distant hope. Additionally, strategic optionality seems
even more limited for the time being with M&A options stopped or stuck. We leave our
2019E EPS largely unchanged but we cut 2020E, 2021E and 2022E by 25%, 18% and
12%. This is predominantly driven by lower revenue assumptions as we delay rate hike
assumptions in-line with market implied levels (a triple digit mio delta). The current
share price implies a 2020E ROTE of 3.7%, 50bp above UBSe. This would imply
EUR300m higher revenues for 2020E. Even with our above-consensus estimates, we
derive a fair value below the current share price. We cut our PT to EUR5.7 (-27%).

11:57 am
JP11:58am

Ongoing headwinds
Revenues in our view remain under pressure and the recent rate outlook doesn’t bode
well for future revenues. In CIB, Deutsche has been losing revenues in absolute and
relative terms. The potential reasons have been discussed extensively here. We still
believe in the medium- to long-term structural change of the German banking market.
In the meantime however, competition remains intense.

LegalEagle Sorry joined late but a cracking good read!
JP11:58am

This seems like the key para:

JP11:58am

Limited strategic optionality
We believe the key for DB and the share price performance will be credit/debt markets.
As we said in a recent note, DB’s IB would have been a key beneficiary of a deal with
Commerz, as it could have helped to drive down funding costs and spreads and
balance the overall profile. The investment case is back to our thesis laid out in our Jan
2019 note with the most likely path being a ‘muddle through’ approach whereby DB
tries to cuts costs while growing and defending the revenue base. We therefore also
don’t expect any radical strategic moves short-term.

11:58 am
JP11:58am

Valuation: Inexpensive if revenues stabilise and recover
There are three upside risks to our call. Firstly, rates go up earlier than expected.
Secondly, M&A could support the share price and, thirdly, better than expected
operating conditions particularly in CIB. Also, ‘technical’ changes around ADI, CDS and
G-SIB buffers could be supportive (see note for details and abbreviations). Our PT is
based on a GGM using the 2020E ROTE of 3.2%, growth of 1% and COE of 11%.

JP11:59am

A return on tangible equity of 3.2 per cent. Yeesh.

red needs a french german partnership. i dont see the americans keen
JP11:59am

And Commerzbank, down 3.31pc at E7.42

TB Bit early to downgrade DB
12:00 pm
JP12:00pm

Downgrade to Neutral given lower profit forecast. We cut PT to CHF7.4 (-27%)Commerz’s share price is up c35% YTD. We lower our EPS 2019E, 2020E, 2021E and 2022E EPS by 9%, 23%, 23% and 22%. Risk/reward is now more balanced and we cut our rating to Neutral. There are three reasons for the EPS cuts: Firstly, our bank levy assumptions were cEUR150m too low. Secondly, we do not anymore explicitly factor in revenue benefits in 2020 and beyond coming from rising rates (was some EUR200m p.a.). Thirdly, our corporate center loss is now more in-line with guidance (EUR60m delta). We leave costs assumptions unchanged (EUR6.58bn 2020E vs EUR6.5bn target). The current share price reflects a 2020E ROTE largely in-line with our c4% estimate

JP12:00pm

Biggest headwind remains low and negative ratesRising rates are a distant hope at the moment. We now see underlying revenue up 1% in 2019E (2.6% before) and we cut 2020/2019 from +5.3% to +1.5% as we remove rate benefits. We now expect NII to grow c5% in PSBC (retail, SME) and CC (corporates) in 2019E (Q1 was +9% y/y). Balance sheet growth was c10% in Q1 (c8% for 2019E) but this will be dragged down by ongoing margin pressure in our view.

JP12:00pm

Competition in Germany remains intense in the meantimeWe still believe in the medium- to long-term structural change of the German banking market. In the meantime however, competition remains intense whereby most players try to compensate margin pressure by boosting volumes – with the latter obviously making the margin picture even worse. Other vulnerabilities are too positive revenue expectations, sovereign exposures and bank levies. The ROTE would be some 150bp higher w/o bank levies and it could almost reach the old 6% 2020E ROTE target.

Upaswellasdown Just about morning all. Loved the article in today's FT that GS should buy DB. I think GS would probably be interested in maybe c. 5% of the business?
12:00 pm
JP12:00pm

Valuation: Balanced risk reward profileThere are three upside risks to our call: Firstly, rates go up earlier than expected. Secondly, M&A could support the share price but it doesn’t seem to be imminent. Thirdly, Commerz organises an investor day in autumn 2019. Convincing newsflow at the investors’ day could obviously support the share price. A successful strategy should aim for a ROTE above/at its COE; otherwise independence, capital market access and share price performance could be at risk. Commerz could therefore be forced to further cut costs and initiate further revenue measures. That said, at this point, we struggle to see obvious sources for additional revenues and costs cutting. Price target is based on a one-stage Gordon growth model.

JP12:06pm

The importance of the digital ecosystem is laid bare as the loss of the Google ecosystem is very likely to cost Huawei all of its smartphone shipments outside of China (50% of total in Q4 18 Counterpoint Research).
In response to the executive order that was issued on Wednesday, Google has suspended its business with Huawei meaning that all future Huawei smartphones will be unable to offer users the Google services that they demand.
Huawei will not lose access to Android itself which is open source but Android devices outside of China must offer access to Google services in order to have any prospect of being sold.
This is because device purchasing is now almost entirely driven by the ecosystem with an Android device purchase representing a desire to live one’s Digital Life with Google.
This will also cause difficulties for Huawei in 5G as Qualcomm’s recent crushing defeat of Apple is strong evidence that, at the moment, Qualcomm has the only viable 5G smartphone modem (see here).

JP12:06pm

This is all in compliance with an executive order which placed Huawei on the entity list meaning that any US company shipping product, software or services to Huawei will need a licence from the commerce department.
Google and Qualcomm must now decide whether to apply for a licence and there is no indication as to whether or not they would be successful.
The immediate impact will be negligible as any phone that has already been launched will be unaffected and Huawei has already launched its main devices for 2019.
Furthermore, Huawei claims that it has enough stocks of US components to last 3 months giving it a window to arrive at a solution.
For hardware components, there are plenty of options although some will not be as good as their US counterparts, but for the Google ecosystem and 5G, Huawei is in real trouble.
This is not an exact repeat of the blockade that virtually put ZTE out of business as there is an avenue by which sales can continue but it represents a very serious problem.

Irish HF guy TCG 2012: 19 planes, received proceeds of USD 294.1m (£184.9m) from the sale and leaseback of 11 Boeing 757 aircraft and 2 Boeing 767 aircraft with Guggenheim Aviation Partners LLC, and 6 Boeing 767 aircraft with Aircastle Advisor (International) Limited
12:06 pm
JP12:06pm

I think that the USA has no particular desire to put Huawei out of business, but it does want to have what it considers to be a fair trade deal with China and companies that are dependent on USA technology are a simple way to gain bargaining leverage.
Huawei’s roots are in the Chinese military and as most large Chinese companies have fairly close ties to the government, I see this as merely a negotiating tactic.
Hence, I think that when a trade deal is done either Huawei will be removed from the list or it will become a very simple matter to obtain a licence.
The real potential beneficiary here is Samsung.
In the last 2 years, Huawei has put real pressure on its handset business by substantially eroding its volume advantage.
This advantage, which just 2 years ago was 2 devices shipped for every 1 from Huawei, allowed Samsung to earn margins of 12-14% on smartphones despite selling a commoditised product.
This advantage is now down to 1.2 to 1 and Samsung’s handset margins have taken a substantial hit as a result.
Samsung is no longer meaningfully present in China meaning that Huawei falling away would remove by far its biggest competitor.
Hence, this would herald both a market share jump and a return of the volume advantage that allowed it to make such a good return.
This has not been priced into the shares in any way making Samsung a very interesting stock to consider when looking for ways to offset the potential negative implications of a protracted trade war.
